Thus, mutational analysis of mouse Pch2 ( Trip13), which is also critical for the synapsis checkpoint in C. elegans [ 2], was the best remaining option to evaluate potential functional conservation in mammalian meiotic checkpoint control.

Deletion of PCH2 delays meiotic progression by ~ 2 h in SK1 yeast, and causes a minor decrease in ascus formation [ 50].
Additionally, it was reported that pch2 Delta yeast had a meiosis I delay dependent on the RAD17 - SAE2 checkpoint that monitors recombination intermediates [ 12].
These potential recombination roles might not be limited to meiosis, since Trip13 is widely transcribed and the mutant animals exhibited developmental defects.
Regarding the cause of cell death in Trip13 mutants, our data indicate that this is triggered by defective DSB repair rather than asynapsis.
